body:
hmmmm - what exactly would you expect the happen in this case, @RikStarmans?

Would you expect `f` to take the i-th bootstrap instance of `X` and the i-th bootstrap instance ot `y`?

The bootstrap transformer creates multiple instances, but they bootstrap instances of `X` and `y` will be independently created of each other.

I understand where the discrepancy between status quo and expected is coming from:

* currently, we block all instances where `X` and `y` have a different scitype, for atomic forecasters this typically results in an error
* however, in this case it makes sense for the composite (all three components). The problem is how it is built up - in the middle layer, which is also a forecaster, we have `X` and `y` that do not have the same scitype (number of levels in `pandas`).

We could relax the check and trust the user they are building sth sensible - at the cost that error messages are less informative in some genuine error cases.
(also, I didn't expect anyone to build this kind of pipeline, but it makes sense!)

@fkiraly  this is the use case I currently apply it for.
I have a daily dataset and want to produce a forecast both on weekly and daily levels.
My forecast has to be accurate on the weekly level. I forecast on the weekly levels and then use historic disaggregation
to forecast for the days using the reconcilliator.
This fails, due to the aforementioned issue.

```python
from datetime import timedelta

import pandas as pd

from sktime.forecasting.reconcile import ReconcilerForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.sarimax import SARIMAX
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.transformations.base import BaseTransformer


y = pd.DataFrame(load_airline())
# get a day timestamp
y.index = pd.DatetimeIndex(pd.date_range(y.index.min().to_timestamp(), periods=len(y)))


def list_size(x, tag):
    return (x.get_level_values(tag)
             .unique()
             .size)


class Week(BaseTransformer):
    _tags = {
        "scitype:transform-input": "Series",
        "scitype:transform-output": "pd_multiindex_hier",
        "scitype:transform-labels": "None",
        "_output_convert": False,
        # todo instance wise?
        "scitype:instancewise": True,  # is this an instance-wise transform?
        "X_inner_mtype": [
            "pd.Series",
            "pd.DataFrame",
            "pd-multiindex",
            "pd_multiindex_hier",
        ],
        "y_inner_mtype": "None",  # which mtypes do _fit/_predict support for y?
        "capability:inverse_transform": False,  # does transformer have inverse
        "skip-inverse-transform": True,  # is inverse-transform skipped when called?
        "univariate-only": False,  # can the transformer handle multivariate X?
        "handles-missing-data": False,  # can estimator handle missing data?
        "X-y-must-have-same-index": False,  # can estimator handle different X/y index?
        "fit_is_empty": True,  # is fit empty and can be skipped? Yes = True
        "transform-returns-same-time-index": False,
    }
    def __init__(self):
        super(Week, self).__init__()

    def _transform(self, X, y=None):
        X_hat = X.copy()
        level = X_hat.index.name
        number = (X_hat.groupby(pd.Grouper(level=level,
                                           freq='W-MON',
                                           closed='left',
                                           label='left'))
                       .count()
                       .median()
                       .sum())
        grp_week = pd.Grouper(level=level,
                              freq='W-MON',
                              closed='left',
                              label='left')
        grp_day = pd.Grouper(level=level,
                             freq='D')
        X_hat = (X_hat.groupby([grp_week])
                      .filter(lambda x:
                             x.count().sum() == number)
                      .groupby([grp_week, grp_day])
                      .first())
        X_hat.index.set_names(['week', 'day'], inplace=True)
        weeks = list_size(X_hat.index, 'week')
        new_index = (pd.MultiIndex
                       .from_product([range(weeks), range(7)],
                                     names=['week', 'day']))
        X_hat = (X_hat.set_index(new_index)
                      .reorder_levels(["day", "week"])
                      .sort_index(level='day'))
        return X_hat

#Week().fit_transform(y)    
f = Week()*(Week()**ReconcilerForecaster(SARIMAX(), method='td_fcst')) 
#Week().fit_transform(y)
f.fit(y=y)
# does not crash
f.fit(y=y,
      X=y)
# gives error of incompatible types
```

See above added example of why I believe I need it. 
I also have a weekback transformer, but removed it here.
Code is not of super high quality but seems to fail, due to afore mentioned issue.

That's a very nice transformer!

We were already thinking how we could do multiple granularity disaggregation and temporal reconcilliation, it appears you figured out how to do it within the current framework (bug aside).

* would be great if could make a PR with the transformer to `sktime`, that way your use case might be easier to debug (and it is nice!)
* for reconciling weekly aggregates, should not the week timestamp the lowest (time-like) index, and the day of the week the second-to-last (instance-like)? Because then the totals will be weekly aggregates.

issue.title: [ENH] reconciliation at different temporal aggregation levels

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
We should include functionality that makes reconciliation at different temporal aggregation levels easy, e.g., weekly and monthly; or weekly, daily, monthly.

I think @rikstarmans has shown in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3776 (in his pasted code) how to do this easiest - simply split up the time stamp in week/day multiindex etc and apply the current reconciler (is that correct, @rikstarmans?)

If that works, we should:

* add the code of @rikstarmans, or a slightly more general version, to `sktime`
* fix the bug in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3776
* possibly wrap the composition (nesting pipeliens is maybe clunky) as a forecaster wrapper

Thoughts?

body:
Good the discussion is separated over two threads.
* To get back on your question, I reorder the levels at the end `.reorder_levels(["day", "week"])`. I believe this solves it.
   I was not able to do the grouping by starting directly with day and week.
* I see three possible solutions, where 2 and 3 are similar.
  I will submit a solution along line 2.
    * overwrite _check_X_y  of the BaseForecaster super class
       in the TransformedTargetForecaster and ForecastingPipeline.
        This allows me to remove the check. I think this is not optimal.
    * I pass a variable, do not check to the BaseForecaster super class, it skips the check.
      This requires only changes on the BaseForecaster class and an additional flag on 
      TransformedTargetForecaster, ForecastingPipeline and maybe ReconcilerForecaster.
    * A solution, similar to above, would be to only execute _check_X_y for forecaster which do computations and use X and y.
      `f = Week()*(Week()**ReconcilerForecaster(SARIMAX(), method='td_fcst'))`
      In the above, this is SARIMAX. Here X has to match y.  You could pass a flag that for SARIMAX X has to match y.
      It is not the case for ReconcilerForecaster. Here possibly a forecasting pipeline could be passed,
      which contains a transformation that ensures X and y are aligned.
      Note that this solution is very similar to the second solution.

That's a very nice transformer!

We were already thinking how we could do multiple granularity disaggregation and temporal reconcilliation, it appears you figured out how to do it within the current framework (bug aside).

* would be great if could make a PR with the transformer to `sktime`, that way your use case might be easier to debug (and it is nice!)
* for reconciling weekly aggregates, should not the week timestamp the lowest (time-like) index, and the day of the week the second-to-last (instance-like)? Because then the totals will be weekly aggregates.
whoops, this response was stuck for one day somehow, I saw you already opened the PR - thanks! You must have been reading my thoughts.

issue.title: [BUG] Remove check_X_y for pipelines

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Fixes https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3776, bug is linked to https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3790.

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
A forecaster which contains a transformer for both X and Y and converts series to panel, cannot be used.
The following forecaster does not make sense. Operations like these are needed for temporal aggregators.
```python
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveForecaster
from sktime.transformations.bootstrap import STLBootstrapTransformer
y = load_airline()
f = STLBootstrapTransformer()*(STLBootstrapTransformer()**NaiveForecaster())
f.fit(y=y)
# fail in the current code base, due to TypeError: X and y must have the same scitype
# it should not fail as X and y have the same type after the trafos
# this is fixed by this push
f.fit(y=y,
      X=y)
# the following still results in a TypeError
f = NaiveForecaster()
try:
    f.fit(y=y,
          X=STLBootstrapTransformer().fit_transform(y))
except TypeError:
    print('Catched a type error as expected')
```

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No
<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?
Maybe a test needs to be added based upon the example given above.
Changes are in line with Franz his proposal.
<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->
I added a lot of doc strings to the forecaster class which document the expected behaviour.
This is in line with sktime but it is a repetitive pattern and in my opinion bad coding style.

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [x] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [MNT], [DOC], or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, maintenance, documentation, or bug.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body:
I wanted to reply on this, apologies.

> I see three possible solutions, where 2 and 3 are similar. I will submit a solution along line 2.

I think there are two "principled" ways, and we should not hack the base class (or this will lead to trouble...)
Both follow your no.2; one of them is quicker to implement.

1. the "deep" solution is having config flags that control input and output checks. This should not happen via "raw attributes" but use the tag/config system. It is actually sth I'm working on.

2. a shorter term solution would be introducing a tag, e.g., `"X-y-must-have-same-scitype"`, if it is `False`, then the check inside `_check_X_y` would be turned off (but not the entire checking machinery!)
Adding a tag is slightly involved, but you can bootstrap the logic if you search for `"X-y-must-have-same-index"` in `BaseForecaster` and in the `registry` module. On current main, the key logic that applies it in forecaster checks is in line 1359 of `BaseForecaster`. Where the new tag would have to play a role is line 1365, shortly after.
Would you like to give option 2 a try? It's a more principled version of #3794.
I will look into it tomorrow and change the pull request.
